meta.content: Here, we report a synthetic strategy for fabricating silica-encapsulated gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) on magnetic particle (Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2) for use as a magnetically-separable, thermally-stable, and easily recyclable catalyst in liquid phase reactions. Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2 samples were prepared by synthesizing a Fe3O4@SiO2 core–shell particle followed by decoration with the Au NPs and additional mesoporous silica coating. The prepared Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2 catalysts showed advantageous characteristics for liquid phase reaction, which are superparamagnetic properties for easy separation and recycling, the well-developed mesoporosity on the outer surface for facile diffusion of reactant molecules, and high resistance on thermal sintering of Au NPs. The resulting core–shell-type catalysts showed improved performance in terms of catalytic stability and recyclability for multiple reaction runs. In particular, the Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2-H2O catalyst, which is treated with additional water etching, showed optimal properties such as improved molecular accessibility and Au stability, resulting in the best catalytic performance seen in this study.

meta.content: Magnetically-Separable and Thermally-Stable Au Nanoparticles Encapsulated in Mesoporous Silica for Catalytic Applications - Topics in Catalysis

Here, we report a synthetic strategy for fabricating silica-encapsulated gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) on magnetic particle (Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2) for use as a magnetically-separable, thermally-stable, and easily recyclable catalyst in liquid phase reactions. Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2 samples were prepared by synthesizing a Fe3O4@SiO2 core–shell particle followed by decoration with the Au NPs and additional mesoporous silica coating. The prepared Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2 catalysts showed advantageous characteristics for liquid phase reaction, which are superparamagnetic properties for easy separation and recycling, the well-developed mesoporosity on the outer surface for facile diffusion of reactant molecules, and high resistance on thermal sintering of Au NPs. The resulting core–shell-type catalysts showed improved performance in terms of catalytic stability and recyclability for multiple reaction runs. In particular, the Fe3O4@SiO2-Au@mSiO2-H2O catalyst, which is treated with additional water etching, showed optimal properties such as improved molecular accessibility and Au stability, resulting in the best catalytic performance seen in this study.

div.p:

The resulting core–shell-type catalysts showed improved performance in terms of catalytic stability and recyclability for multiple reaction runs. In particular, the Fe

Designing a novel catalyst with high performance is an important issue in catalysis research, since the overall performance of a catalytic process is highly dependent on the catalyst. Generally, heterogeneous catalysts can be synthesized by the introduction of active sites on support materials, followed by thermal treatment. Although thermally-treated catalysts can have advantageous characteristics such as good interaction between the active sites and the support, clean surface of active metal, and considerable stability, unfortunately, the control in terms of both active metal size and dispersion of active sites is difficult due to unpredictable thermal sintering [
1
,
2
]. In addition, it is challenging to introduce other functions into the catalysts, since additional functions can improve the overall efficiency of the catalytic process [
3
–
5
].

Over the past decade, researchers have exerted extensive efforts not only to controlling active site properties but also to introducing additional functions into the catalyst [
3
,
6
,
7
]. With developments in synthetic chemistry, researchers can control the characteristics of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials in terms of chemical properties such as composition and electronic properties, as well as physical properties such as particle size, shape, and structure. In particular, since various concepts surrounding novel nanostructures have been introduced, a novel class of heterogeneous catalysts with well-defined nanostructures have been synthesized and applied to many catalytic reactions [
8
–
10
]. When nanostructured catalysts consist of different materials in a well-defined individual particle, for instance a core–shell particle with different components, multiple functions originating from each material can easily be facilitated [
3
,
4
,
11
].

Heterogeneous catalysts that can participate in practical liquid phase reactions have several requirements to achieve high performance. In order to obtain high activity, the catalysts should have well-defined active sites with a large active surface area, high dispersion, clean surface, and large resistance to thermal sintering [
1
,
6
,
7
,
12
]. It would be fair to assume that one can directly use pre-synthesized nanoparticles as active sites, since colloidal nanoparticles are monodispersed and well-defined structures that can provide a large active surface area [
6
,
13
,
14
]. However, nanoparticles are usually stabilized by the capping agent such as a surfactant, which can not only limit access to the reactant but also hamper surface reaction. In order to remove the capping agent and make the surface clean, nanoparticles can be charged to calcination at a high temperature. Although few nice works on removal of capping agent have been demonstrated, metal nanoparticles are generally sintered and deformed during calcination, leading to a loss of the unique behavior seen in the original ones [
6
,
15
–
17
].

Recently, it was realized that capping agents can be removed without any metal sintering by encapsulating a nanoparticle within a nanoscale layer to form a core–shell nanostructure, followed by calcination. To date, a lot of pioneering work has successfully demonstrated encapsulation of nanoparticles within nanoscale inorganic thin layers [
7
,
18
,
19
]. Although the above encapsulation strategy is efficient for the stabilization of metal nanoparticles and the elongation of their unique properties, the dense layer can hinder reactant molecules from reaching the embedded metal surface, thus limiting surface reaction. Practically, although a thin silica layer deposited on a metal surface has a diameter of only several nanometers, it can effectively prevent the permeation of molecules and ions [
6
,
18
,
20
,
21
]. Thus, considering the accessibility of reactant molecules and the thermal stability of active metal, the layer of protection should be thin and porous, allowing reactant molecules to reach the metal surface and isolating each particle from thermal sintering.

Another essential issue in liquid phase reactions is separation and recycling. A well-dispersed catalyst must be separated out and recycled for further use. The catalyst is usually separated by filtration and/or centrifugation from liquid media. When a catalyst with fine particles is separated by filtration, the loss of catalyst sample could be significant, since fine particles can be strongly attached to the surface of the filter paper or membrane, leading to difficulty in the complete recovery of all particles. Although centrifugation provides another manner by which to separate fine catalyst particles, an expensive centrifugation unit is required, and it takes a long time to achieve satisfactory separation. In order to accomplish feasible and economical separation, a simple method is preferred. An external magnetic field can be a good candidate for the separation of a solid catalyst from liquid media, when the catalysts have a magnetic-responsive component. It is known that well-defined magnetic nanostructures, which can be responsive to external magnetic stimuli, can be successfully synthesized and applied to various applications including adsorption, catalysis, and photonic crystals [
22
–
25
]. In practical applications, solid particles with a magnetic component can be easily separated out using an magnet and reused by simple sonication for the next run.

In this work, we synthesized Au NPs-encapsulated Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au@mSiO
2
particles and demonstrated their use as multifunctional catalysts that are magnetically separable, thermally stable, and feasibly reusable. In order to improve molecular accessibility, we introduced a mesoporous layer and carried out additional water etching. We systematically characterized the physical and chemical properties of Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au@mSiO
2
samples and investigated their catalytic performance in 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction as a model reaction. In addition, catalytic activities in multiple runs were investigated to verify the enhancement of catalyst stability.

div.h3:
Synthesis of Fe
3
O
4
Particles and Au Nanoparticles (Au NPs)
div.p:
Spherical Fe
3
O
4
particles were prepared by solvothermal synthesis [
25
]. The specific amounts of FeCl
3
, trisodium citrate dehydrate (TSC), and sodium acetate (NaOAc) were dissolved in ethylene glycol (EG) under vigorous stirring. Once the chemicals were completely dissolved, the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 200 °C. After 10 h, a black precipitate (Fe
3
O
4
particles) was obtained. This material was washed with ethanol and water, and the solution was re-dispersed in 20 ml DI Water.

Small Au nanoparticles (2–4 nm) were prepared by a conventional reduction method [
6
]. Briefly, aqueous solutions of HAuCl
4
and TSC were sequentially added to DI Water, and the mixture was stirred vigorously for 10 min. An aqueous NaBH
4
solution was quickly injected into the solution, and the yellow color was rapidly changed to red, indicating the formation of small Au NPs. Subsequently, an aqueous solution of PVP (polyvinyl -pyrrolodone) was added and kept in the refrigerator for further use.

The Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au sample was prepared by coating the Fe
3
O
4
particle with SiO
2
, followed by Au NP decoration. Coating of Fe
3
O
4
with SiO
2
layer was carried out by the modified Stober method [
14
,
26
]. The Fe
3
O
4
particles were dispersed in a mixture of ethanol and water using a mechanical stirrer. Solutions of NH
4
OH and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were sequentially added, and the mixture was stirred for 6 h. The resulting Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
particles were separated, collected with a neodymium magnet, and washed with ethanol. Finally, the particles were re-dispersed in ethanol for further use.

In order to decorate Au NPs on the surface of Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
, an amine functional group was introduced. (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) was slowly added to the ethanolic solution of Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
, and the mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 6 h to ensure complete functionalization. The precipitated particles were separated by a magnet, washed 3 times with ethanol and water, and re-dispersed in water. APTES-functionalized Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
solution was then added to the PVP-coated Au NP solution under ultra-sonication conditions. After 3 h, the resulting particles were collected by a magnet and washed 3 times with ethanol to obtain Fe
3
O
4
@SiO

Following the addition of aqueous ammonia, TEOS was added dropwisely to the mixture under mechanical stirring conditions. The mixture was stirred overnight under ambient conditions. The precipitate was then collected using a neodymium magnet and washed with ethanol. The precipitate was dried under vacuum conditions, and the dried sample was calcined at 500 °C to burn out the surfactants. Finally, the Fe
3

An aqueous solution containing Fe

3

@SiO

2

The particle morphology and metal dispersion were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SEC SNE-3000M). The crystalline properties were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/MAX 2500) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The magnetic properties of the samples were evaluated using a vibrating sample magnetometer, and the pore properties were evaluated by N
2
adsorption at 77 K (Micrometrics ASAP 2010).

The catalytic performance was investigated by 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction as a model reaction. DI water, aqueous 4-NP solution, and NaBH
4
solution (0.1 M, 0.1 ml) were added into a quartz cuvette, followed by the addition of the catalyst sample solution in order to initialize the reaction. In each reaction run, the same amount of Au (75 μg) was used in the reaction media. Catalytic efficiency was evaluated by calculating the degradation rate of 4-NP. The change in concentration of 4-NP in the solution was monitored by measuring the UV–Vis absorption spectra of the reaction mixture by using spectrophotometer (UV-1800, Shimazdu).

1
. Magnetic Fe
3
O

25

3

4

6

2

1
,
6

Consequently, the porous silica layer was introduced, which can isolate individual Au NPs and prevent the particles from being sintered even after high temperature calcination. Due to the fact that a long enough reaction time can provide >99% conversion in 4-NP reduction, although active metals are sintered and detached from supports, the conversion values of each catalyst were compared in multiple runs at fixed reaction times based on the achievement of >99% conversion on the 1st run. We have demonstrated that a magnetically-separable Au catalyst encapsulated in a mesoporous silica layer can be used as a recyclable catalyst in liquid phase reactions. The catalyst synthesis involved following sequential steps: solvothermal synthesis of superparamagnetic Fe
3
O
4
particles, sol–gel coating of a SiO
2
layer, decoration of Au NP on the silica surface, and formation of a mesoporous silica layer followed by calcination. The Fe
3
O
4
core can serve as a magnetic-responsive component that is used for facile separation and recycling. Encapsulated Au NPs cannot be sintered even at high temperature calcination, and the surfactant-free clean surfaces of Au NPs can act as active sites in catalysis. An outer mesoporous shell provides not only a physical barrier to prevent Au sintering, but also a diffusion pathway for favorable surface reaction. Although Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au, with naked Au NPs, exhibited high conversion and rapid reaction kinetics in the first run, the Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au@mSiO
2
catalyst showed better performance with higher conversion and more stable activity during multiple reaction runs. Among the tested catalysts, Fe
3
O
4
@SiO
2
-Au@mSiO
2
-H
2
O treated by water etching showed the best performance in terms of activity and recyclability, since molecule diffusion is enhanced and highly-dispersed Au NPs are stable during catalysis. It is believed that the concept of our encapsulated metal catalyst provides a good opportunity for the synthesis of stable noble metal nanocatalysts for various applications.
